Reference¶

virtool.job.db¶

Globals and utility functions for interacting with the application database.

virtool.job.db.PROJECTION = ['_id', 'task', 'status', 'proc', 'mem', 'user']¶

The default MongoDB projection for job documents.

virtool.job.db.processor(document)[source]¶

The default document processor for job documents. Transforms projected job documents to a structure that can be dispatches to clients.

  1. Removes the status and args fields from the job document.
  2. Adds a username field.
  3. Adds a created_at date taken from the first status entry in the job document.
  4. Adds state and progress fields derived from the most recent status entry in the job document.
Parameters:document (dict) – a document to process
Return type:dict
Returns:a processed document

virtool.job.job¶

Classes, exceptions, and utilities for creating Virtool jobs.

class virtool.job.job.Job(db_connection_string, db_name, settings, job_id, q)[source]¶

Job can be subclassed to create new jobs that are compatible with Virtool.

Parameters:
  • db_connection_string (str) – the MongoDB connection string for the application database server
  • db_name (str) – the name of the application MongoDB database
  • settings (dict) – a dict of settings that will be used by the job
  • job_id (str) – the job’s unique ID that should already be associated with a job document in the database
  • q –
db_connection_string¶

The application database server connection string. See Connection String URI Format in the MongoDB documentation.

db_name¶

The name of the application database.

settings¶

A dict of application settings passed into the job when it was created.

id¶

The job’s unique ID. It is associated with the job’s database document.

q¶

A bidirectional multiprocessing.Queue used for passing dispatch instructions to the API server.

This queue is not used if message passing through Redis is enabled.

db¶

An instance of pymongo.database.Database connected to the MongoDB database specified by db_connection_string and db_name.

Value is None until init_db() is called.

task_name¶

The name of the job task (eg. create_sample).

Value is None until init_db() is called.

task_args¶

Arguments attached to the job document by the API server.

Value is None until init_db() is called.

proc¶

The core limit for the job.

Value is None until init_db() is called.

mem¶

The memory limit for the job.

Value is None until init_db() is called.

params¶

A dict for storing parameters that will direct the job run. Parameters should be assigned in the redefinition of the check_db() method.

intermediate¶

A dict for storing data to be carried between stage methods.

results¶

A dict for storing results that should be written to file or database at the end of the job.

init_db()[source]¶

Called in the run() method when the job starts.

Initializes a database client using the db_connection_string and db_name attributes.

The job document is fetched and used to set the task_name, task_args, proc, and mem attributes.

check_db()[source]¶

Intended to be redefined in subclasses of Job.

This method is called immediately after init_db(), Populate the Job.params state attribute here. These values are used to provide application data to the stage methods.

Isolating calculation of Job.params to this method simplifies the mocking required for unit testing individual stage methods.

run()[source]¶

The main job execution method. Methods in Job.stage_list are executed sequentially.

If SIGTERM is received, execution of stage methods is stopped and the job is put into the cancelled state by calling add_status().

If an error is encountered in a stage method or a subprocess, execution of stage methods is stopped. The error is recorded in Job._error and the job is put into the error state by calling add_status().

Any dangling subprocess is killed and cleanup() is called if the job fails.

dispatch(interface, operation, id_list)[source]¶

Using the job’s messaging interface (multiprocessing.Queue or Redis), send an instruction to the API server(s) to dispatch messages for the passed interface, operation and id_list.

Operations can be one of: insert, update, or remove.

Consider this call to Job.dispatch():

dispatch(
    "update",
    "analyses",
    ["ahj26ka"]
)

The above call would instruct the API server to dispatch the most recent version of the database document with the unique id ahj26ka in the analyses collection.

This is useful when the job updates parts of the database and you want users to receive real time updates for the affected documents. For example, building a new reference index and setting the ready flag to True on the database document representing the index. Sending a real-time update to the clients would allow the index UI component to change from a pending to active style.

Parameters:
  • interface (str) – the interface (ie. database collection) the message applies to
  • operation (str) – the operation to perform on the interface
  • id_list (list) – a list of ids whose documents should be dispatched

See also

How-to documentation for Dispatching.

cleanup()[source]¶

Called when the job fails due to error or cancellation. It should clean up any files or database changes made by the job prior to its failure.

By default, this method does nothing. It is intended to be replaced in a subclass.

virtool.job.job.handle_exception(max_tb=50)[source]¶

Transforms an exception into a dict describing the error. The dict can be stored in MongoDB and used to annotate a job document.

Usage:

try:
    cause_error()
except:
    error = handle_exception()
Parameters:max_tb (Optional[int]) – maximum traceback depth
Return type:dict
Returns:traceback data
virtool.job.job.handle_sigterm(*args)[source]¶

A handler for SIGTERM signals. Raises a TerminationError in Job.run() that allows the job to clean-up after itself before terminating.

A SIGTERM is generally received as the result of explicit cancellation of the job by a user.

virtool.job.job.watch_pipe(stream, q)[source]¶

A function for watching stdout and stderr pipes on subprocesses. Lines are read and pushed into the q. Queued lines are handled in Job.run().

This function is intended to be run in a separate thread.

Parameters:
  • stream (TextIOWrapper) – a stdout or stderr file object
  • q (Queue) – a queue to push lines into

Utility functions.

virtool.job.utils.timestamp()[source]¶

Returns a datetime object representing the current UTC time. The last 3 digits of the microsecond frame are set to zero.

Returns:a UTC timestamp
Return type:datetime.datetime
